review_title: A great place to work, doing great work, for a great university
job_title: Academic Peer Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: The fact that you know you are doing great and influential work for one of the best universities in Canada and the world. UBC also has very nice benefits, including competitive pay (which seems to be above average compared to others) and also some tuition credits for those that are employed at UBC. People at UBC are warm and friendly and have a nice attitude towards meeting new staff and faculty. Many professors there are extremely intelligent and knowledgeable about their specialty and if you take the tuition credit, you will learn quite a bit from some of the courses.
cons: One downside is that if you do not live on campus, it can be a long commute in to work at UBC. UBC and the area around UBC also has fairly high rent compared to other places. The campus itself is a very large place and walking around the campus can be a lengthy walk depending on where you work compared to where the bus loop is (or however you are commuting). If you decide to drive up to UBC, parking is quite expensive though it may be cheaper if you purchase monthly parking passes. There are plenty of parking places so that is one good thing about driving.

review_title: Pros and cons of working in an administrative/managerial role for UBC
pros: The best thing about working for UBC is the calibre of your colleagues - dedicated, educated, motivated professionals who go above and beyond the call of duty. Staff salaries are competitive if perhaps not as high as you could achieve in the private sector; extended health and dental benefits are good; tuition waiver is a bonus if you or a dependent is enrolled at UBC. Depending on the department and your role, you may have some flexibility with working hours or the opportunity to work remotely sometimes. The Vancouver campus is beautiful and offers a lot to do, see and enjoy (when you're not working).
cons: Opportunities for promotion can be sparse - once you have made yourself valuable in a role you may not be considered for others. There is a bit of a tendency to value external candidates - especially young candidates coming from the private sector - as more valuable than internal candidates with years of public post-secondary specific experience.  Culture in some departments expect you to be "on duty" 24/7 due to staffing cutbacks and funding shortfalls.

review_title: Cushy benefits dull the pain of any other ongoing issues.
pros:
Benefits and perks are amazing. I am part of "Management and Professional" employee category with:
35 hr work week
4 weeks paid vacation to start. 
3 weeks paid sick days to start, then after 1st yr I believe that can even get long term disability if needed.
Company pays 100% of extended health benefits that includes good packages for vision and dental.
Good support for professional development, and as this is university get a credit for tuition for any courses you may want to take. 
My department allowed "flex" time. So I work 7.75 hr days for 9 days and get every second Friday off. 
Blessed with a great set of co-workers. Many very bright and talented people.
cons:
For my department I found the work not very challenging, and the work we did was not really up to industry standards in private sector. 
A lot of politics in my department as well. For example endless positive blather about  "long term strategic initiatives" yadda, yadda and then seemingly endless politics that basically torpedoes these plans when upper management and/or sub-departments compete and snipe at each other.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Vancouver, BC
pros: Full time employers having achieved a few years of full time work can qualify for pension plan, UBC offers courses to employees.
cons: Very little and much below average salary to industry norm, no health care benefits, insufficient support from UBC ethical management.  Policy favours employers, such as Vancouver Coastal Health and Providence Health Care Research Institute, to abuse contract employees by giving very low salary with no health care coverage and no pension.

pros:
I have worked at UBC for 15 years as an M&P employee.  UBC is a wonderful place to work.  I feel empowered, appreciated and know that I make a difference every day.  Some pros are:
1. benefit and pension plan
2. opportunities for advancement
3. Professional development
4. great people
cons: The top of my list of cons is the often difficult central systems and administration.  However, in such a large organization, with many unions, it is not surprising.  Another con is the lack of communication from central to the departments.  However, this is not consistent from department to department, suggesting that it is a people problem downstream.

review_title: Awesome Campus and Awesome people but be hyper aware of UBC Politics
job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Vancouver, BC
pros:
* Beautiful campus. You can really enjoy coming to this environment for work.
* Strong diversity and the presence of students everywhere add to that.
* A desire by co-workers to learn and do the right thing.
* Projects are exciting and interesting.
* Excellent co-workers. Some among the best i've ever worked with.
* Academic environment seems to contribute to a learning workforce as well as a highly-educated one.
* Opportunity to shine if you want
cons:
* Expensive to live in Vancouver - even with subsidized staff housing available on campus.
* Need to be careful about changing things too fast. There is a lot of history to unravel to explain campus politics between faculties and between faculties and staff. It's possible, but you need to be aware of it.
* IT systems have 'evolved' organically and thus UBC is both ahead of the times in some areas but also woefully behind the times in others. At one time multiple IT operations each doing their own thing. Consolidation is going slowly and some faculties may never join up.

review_title: Students should themselves on the payroll with the WorkStudy program
job_title: Work Study Research Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: It is a beautiful campus. UBC's WorkStudy program provides a great deal of flexibility and offers reasonable pay for students while they are pursuing ther degrees. Working under professor, I get to learn more than I ordinarily would, and this also enables one to get his/hers foot in the door if interested in pursuing further employment with UBC.  It is also a great way to learn more about the university from the employee's perspective to get a feel for what it's like to work there.
cons: The university work environment as a whole seems somewhat beurocratic, and unreceptive to change. The WorkStudy program is somewhat lacking is structure, and some of the less demanding positions are not offering adequate compensation.

review_title: Staff Members are treated as inferior by Academics
pros: Opportunities to move around as soon as you are an employee. Employees also get professional development funds, and access to courses and course subsidies.
cons: If your supervisor is an Academic, they may end up emailing you hundreds of emails throughout the night (when you are sleeping). So when you wake up, you have a hundred emails to deal with before you start your day. Work / life balance does not happen.

review_title: Very friendly and supportive co-workers, but limited by bureaucracy.
pros: Very friendly, health-oriented work environment with great co-workers. I am proud to be working on something that will benefit the general public, and there is great flexibility for hours. Pay is stable and relatively good for Vancouver.
cons: There are definitely some challenges in getting things done on-time in a big organization, and this is particularly true for UBC. It's particularly frustrating to be forced to use old technology when newer (and cheaper) alternatives are available... but the need for security trumps usability and timelines.

review_title: Great benefits, OK salary, beautiful campus, great opportunities for continual learning
pros: I love working with the students.  They are excited, motivated and have their whole careers and lives ahead of them.  There are lots of resources for information and learning in such a large university. The department I work in is fun, although we all work very hard.
cons: Decisions do not happen quickly and often there are roadblocks to more flexible work arrangements and work processes.  Faculty on the whole, do not value the contributions of staff. Every year, there seem to be more cutbacks and an expectation of doing more with less.

review_title: Unappreciated & Underpaid for Level of Responsibility
pros: Benefits are OK and access to equipment is good.  Things are relatively lax, but sometimes too lax.
cons: Little support from senior admin to resolve conflicts.  Work schedules during regular teaching terms are completely unrealistic & when things go wrong the support staff are always the 1st to be blame.  The coodinators cram too many students in each lab meaning many students have virtually no practical experience before they graduate. Space is very limited which adds to the problem.  Pay is extremely low for the level of responsibility & amount of work involved.  There is a high employee turnover in the support staff but it doesn't seem to matter much to the admins.

review_title: Recreation department: Intramurals and also Marketing
pros:
- Interesting challenges.
- Work alongside students.
- Beautiful campus.
cons:
- Non-equitable recruitment: preference for former Recreation students in these roles.
- All department management staff have ONLY worked in this department: hence lack ability of wider real-world work practices. 
- LONG (outside of pay) hours with no extra compensation. 
- Zero preference and department support for individual professional development opportunities. 
- Minimal promotion opportunities.
- Short lifespan - employees move on quickly.

review_title: It's what you make of it
pros:
Great when your considering a career change as the Uni covers a lot of different employment categories.

There are plenty of opportunities for professional learning with tuition waiver.  

Good opportunities for advancement but you must be willing to move between departments so networking is key. 

Excellent benefits.
cons:
Faculty can be hard to deal with as many are hired for research prowess not people management or (god forbid) financial management skills. 

Senior management can seem very far away. I've worked for departments that fall under Faculty of science and medicine but I can't say either ave made big efforts to engage their workers. 

Some people will spend years (in some cases decades) in the same job so they can find change hard to accept. 

There's a big disconnect between the department on the admin side of things (I think it's better in terms of research collaboration)

review_title: A good piece of woodwork to crawl into
pros:
Very good salaries for low-level jobs.
Very good benefits, lots of vacation time.
Relaxed, informal atmosphere.
Beautiful campus.
You get to work with interesting, sometimes eccentric people, especially in the library, which seems to be a refuge for those who don't quite fit anywhere else in society (I myself fall into this category).
cons:
Salary scales are so compressed, there's no point in rising in the non-management hierarchy. These are essentially high-quality dead-end jobs.
Office politics and soap opera run rampant, especially when people are bored with their jobs.
Many people in management positions, especially librarians, have had no management training. Some of them do a good job, but others are either unable or unwilling to properly supervise their staff members.
It's very expensive to park on campus, even for university staff.

review_title: UBC IT used to be a wonderful place to work, but in recent years many staff have been terminated without cause.
job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Vancouver, BC
pros: UBC has historically provided good benefits, including tuition waivers, a stable pension plan, and generous vacation days. UBC Vancouver Point Grey is beautiful campus. There are many excellent co-workers, and opportunities to participate in some of the events and activities happening in and around the university.
cons: What was previously a collaborative and cooperative work environment has become much more tense and adversarial as more and more managers come in from corporate backgrounds rather than from academic IT positions. Recent frequent layoffs without cause are very demoralizing to the remaining staff. Managers are willing to sacrifice their employees to appeal to upper management.

pros: It's safe here. If you don't screw up badly, you won't lose your job (mostly). The pay is a bit lower than private, benefit is just on par, job description is exactly as-is, you won't be asked to do any work outside of your job description. Some positions are CUPE, so you can think of any Union benefits. Certain employment groups get 4 weeks vacation to start.
cons: Quite hard to move up. You do your job within your job description, so how can you learn more skills and move up? Benefits are on par, but honestly it's not that good. For example, certain employment groups will have to pay 100% of your MSP.

review_title: Supportive and friendly work environment and interesting work
pros: Supportive and engaged work environment, lots of smart and experienced coworkers. Really enjoyed every person I worked with and never felt left out in the cold or without the help I needed. Everyone took the student experience very seriously and worked as hard as possible to make UBC students have a good time.
cons: Very bureaucratic and politically correct. Felt like a lot of time was wasted doing things that weren't necessary, but required by managers, when workload stacked up. Don't tell inappropriate jokes here.

pros: The other volunteer staff that are in the organization are fantastic. The community that is formed from everyone being students and they are there because they want to be there. My time at UBC would be drastically if it wasn't for UBC Rec.
cons: Sometimes the professional staff forget that we are volunteer staff and view them more as employees. They start to expect certain things to take precedence over academics even though you are there on your own will and giving your time. The professional staff micro manage at times which can cause some differences if you are having opposing opinions or perspectives

pros: the benefits are very good
cons: the not-great and sometimes difficult commute, and the disrespect shown to mostly female workers by negotiating low contracts with CUPE 2950 for several years.

pros: The best reason is my department. It's one of the top departments in my field in all North America. In addition, my colleagues are generally supportive of my work, and of my graduate students. It helps that UBC is in Vancouver. My department is Asian Studies, and Vancouver is a great place to do Asian Studies. I don't need to explain the relevance of what I do.
cons: Class size, especially at the 3rd and 4th year level. Class sizes have been rising over the years and are now, for 3rd year and 4th year students, beyond the size that allows me to get to know my students, and tailor the class to their wants and abilities.

review_title: Great experience, but not the same for everyone
job_title: Work Study Student in Vancouver, BC
pros: My supervisor cultivated a positive work environment that was very student-oriented. I worked at the same place for 3 years and I feel like I learned more than I did in my 4 years of undergrad. I did a range of tasks from data entry and recruiting participants to writing reports and presenting powerpoints.
cons: There is little support outside of your supervisor and immediate work area. I have heard some awful things about supervisors abusing their position as a superior, getting students to work more hours than they are paid and never even getting a chance to communicate with their supervisor.

job_title: Research Program Coordinator in Vancouver, BC
pros: Very "gentle" environment with excellent culture against discrimination in the workforce, lots of interesting research and activities happening on campus.
cons: Little opportunity for advancement; atmosphere of self-congratulation on the part of senior staff. "Ghetto-ization" of female employees due to their prevalence in clerical roles; men's work is more recognised, receives higher salaries and opportunities for advancement, whereas women's work is assumed to be lower value clerical/support in nature regardless of the tasks actually done.

pros:
Several opportunities to boost your creative portfolio by publishing content for a prestigious institution,

Lots of flexibility with regards to hours,

Friendly team which is genuinely focused on helping you achieve your dreams.
cons:
You can feel hamstrung at times with regards to what you are allowed to publish.

Working with intelligent people most often means working with opinionated people.

You can get yourself stuck in a media firestorm from time to time.

review_title: Few new Teaching positions at the University of British Columbia
job_title: I Am A Senior Instructor in Vancouver, BC
pros: It's located in a beautiful location.  Colleagues I work with are great.  Research opportunities for professorial faculty abound even if grants are not very easy to get.
cons:
Funding has been tight; so as we take up continuously more students, faculty numbers remain the same, the classes -especially in first year- become overcrowded and our ability to do a great job teaching is compromised.  The classroom maintenance also has been minimized affecting the use of technology.
From the point of view of career development, teaching positions have a glass ceiling with few opportunities to advance beyond the 5th year at the University.

pros:
- Nice people
- Slow and relaxing work day...if that's your style
- Flexible hours
- Good life/work balance
- Very well paid salary
- If you're looking for stability, this is the place for you.
cons:
- Very political work environment. Be prepared to play the game.
- You'll find obstruction from higher management at a 110% scale.
- Management is very power hungry. Instead of delegating responsibilities to others they'll want to keep tabs on everything.
- Because of the above reasons, projects that usually take 1 month to complete may take up to 6 months to a year.
- Career advancement is slim.
- Interdepartmental Communication is non-existent. Every faculty and department is segregated in their own little circles.

review_title: Commitment to work life balance and strong leadership, but varies by unit
pros: Beautiful location, strong leadership, great amenities (recreational, cultural, pro-D), benefits, vacation, range of career options available, option to live on campus = no commute.
cons: An inherently innovative organization struggling to get past the bureacracy, hierarchical structure and crippling long and overly consultative decision making processes. Unfortunately the workplace satisfaction is dependent on the individual unit and supervisor (not unlike large organizations).

review_title: UBC review by ten year employee
pros: supportive environment for workers of all sexual orientation and races, great professional development, good health benefits, beautiful campus, good salary scales, nice vacation allotment
cons: too many meetings, micromanaging, no personal responsibility, no job expansion, breaking of cupe rules, no raises after three years, poor working conditions, too many hours of unpaid overtime, travel time uncompensated, too many politics, poor funding for essential services, managers are not properly trained, poor succession planning

review_title: Overall an OK place to live but the salary is unsustainable when the cost of living is factored in.
pros: Generally nice people who are quite intelligent.  Great surroundings if you value the outdoors.  Good city to bring up children in.
cons: Non-competitive salary unless you are an MD.  Typical university system where they only value people they develop which yields a nepotistic environment.  Suffers from a severe case of 'Group Think'

pros: As a graduate student, working as a teaching assistant at UBC is a great way to add income and some work experience while you complete your studies. In addition, depending on your R&D, you can benefit from sub-contract with with industry partners to expand your network and exposure to industry technology prior to graduation.
cons: There are limitations as to the number of hours a graduate student may work during one week, regardless of whether or not the student has the time to take on more work. However, there is flexibility depending on the demand for teacher assistants.

pros: Good benefits (pension, vacation, tuition waiver). Dynamic location that has access to a number of fitness centres.
cons: Working for academics who have no business sense. The faculty where I worked was dominated by males, many who would have benefitted from training in "how not to sexually harass the staff". I was happy to get out, and know many people are looking around for another job. There's also very little opportunity for career advancement, which is just fine with the academics as they think staff are easily replaceable.

review_title: My experience at UBC was mostly positive.
pros: The best part of working for UBC is the salary and benefits. It is also a beautiful campus and is very well serviced by transit. There are many food service outlets and too many coffee shops to count, including five Starbucks outlets. There are many different positions in multiple fields. I worked in office administration and there were always new jobs opening up.
cons: This is a very top heavy bureaucratic environment with many inept managers on power trips. Some departments are great, others are pure hell.

review_title: Incredible benefits, but you'll be ruined for anywhere else
pros:
- M&P employees have insanely awesome benefits: great extended health, 4 weeks of vacation to start and holiday closures, pension (do these even exist any more?), and extremely generous sick/medical time. UBC is the definition of golden handcuffs.
- Salary: M&P salaries can be pretty great, depending on your pay grade and how many years of service you've had. Vancouver is known for having salaries much lower than the rest of the Canadian market, but UBC's M&P salaries are decent.
- Work life balance is pretty great. Depending on the unit you work in, you'll work  mostly 9-5. I rarely work evenings or weekends, and there's a focus from your supervisors on keeping this balance intact.
- Working for a good cause (education) feels good, and keeps many people here for longer than they'd otherwise stay
- Beautiful campus: The Vancouver campus is really picturesque, and has lots of (expensive but plentiful) food options.
- Reputation: UBC is considered to be a top 40 university in the world, and one of the top 25 public universities. Putting UBC on your resume will never hurt your career trajectory.
cons:
- Lack of innovation/stagnation: Maybe this a general downfall of the public sector, but we're about 5-10 years behind the private sector in a number of different ways. Namely technology and HR policies. This can be frustrating if you come from a sector known for new trends/changes (i.e. technology, business, etc.)
- Hierarchical structure: You won't find many departments with flat structures here. The boss is at the top, and they know best. If you're a junior staff member, it can be hard to speak up and be heard by your senior leaders. 
- Lack of mobility: It's difficult to move up in units/departments. If you're early career, this can be extremely frustrating, and you might just leave to get that experience you so badly want.
- Expensive to work here: UBC's salaries may be high, but geez, they really suck it back out of you if you drive to campus. Parking on campus is about $100/month and food options on campus are expensive. Combine this with the high cost of living in YVR, and your paycheques may not go that far. Not really UBC's fault, though.
- No telecommuting: While UBC published a telecommuting policy in recent years, many departments and units fail to follow it. Our unit isn't allowed to telecommute unless it's an emergency or on a once-off basis. This is an outdated approach to work. If UBC wants to recruit and retain talent in a city as expensive as Vancouver, they need to implement a campus-wide telecommuting policy. For real, this time.
- Vancouver vs Okanagan: There's some grumbling back and forth between campuses. We're technically one university, but it can be challenging to communicate or align resources equally across both campuses.
- Lack of engagement among staff: I find UBC to be so enormous and inaccessible as an employer brand, that I don't feel like I really matter here. It would be nice if the university could find a better way to make employees feel engaged with UBC.
- No meritocracy: There's a fair amount of nepotism here, and under-performing staff are not dealt with appropriate. This can be pretty de-moralizing if you take your work seriously.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: Teaching something will make you understand the material much better.  Pay is quite reasonable.  If the prof is good, he/she will help you develop instructional skills.  Opportunity to make an impact on other students' educational experiences.  Income is nice while studying -- right on campus.
cons: There wasn't much training for first time TAs, thus, TA standards varied.  Some TAs were obviously there just for the pay.  Others you can tell genuinely wanted to make a positive difference in other students' learning.  You don't get much feedback from students or profs at the end of the term.

review_title: Could do with some compassion and anti-bullying training in HR.
pros: Good benefits. Point Grey is a beautiful campus to work at. Great co-workers.
cons: The managers and HR personnel could do with a lot of training in dealing with the disabled workers. There main stance seems to be that everything you say is a lie until they see it in writing from a specialist. Their attempt at accommodation is a joke and amounts to putting up a few signs around the office. If you're a good worker bee you'll be treated well here but if you need any kind of accommodation make sure you know what they're going to be prepared to do before you take a job here.

review_title: Okay freedom; moves at a snail's pace
pros:
People are very friendly, and most supervisors have open office doors to talk about any projects or concerns you have as a student.
The pay is also semi-decent for a part-time job with relatively small commitment.
cons: Terrible pacing - expect to have a lead time of at least a month before any new ideas can be tabled or tackled. If you have any new ideas, you need to jump through at least 3 hoops before the idea is even tabled. Too much bureaucracy, not enough communication.

review_title: A place to impact one of the largest educational institutions in Canada
pros: A work culture that values collaboration, consistency  and accuracy. Creates well paying jobs in working environments that allow for personal and professional growth. Situated on a beautiful campus with excellent offices.
cons: The institutional culture of the university is not innovative or risk taking. The university tends to  be conservative in it's attitudes toward new ideas.

pros: this job is relatively well paid considering the amount of effort needed to do it. good university environment. particularly when you teach a course after the first time, it does not require lots of time. students are self motivated.
cons: it is not easy to get the same job year after year, because it is not a tenure track position. the contract is renewed once per term. the job is usually only provided to new phd graduates at ubc to prepare them to the job markets.

pros: UBC has great benefits and is located at a beautiful, diverse and large campus. UBC employees get free admission to the Museum of Anthropology (MOA). Great connection to Vancouver with public transit (although busses tend to be packed during peak hours).
cons:
UBC is large and it really depends where you are located and working. Each department can be very different from another and it depends very much on your supervisor how your overall experience will be. There are great ones, and not so great ones.
Many pay levels are below province average and are not increased for long periods.

pros: Working at UBC was an entirely positive experience: the working environment is outstanding, which is a product of the institution's values and hiring people who are a good fit for its culture. The salary was competitive and there was a high degree of understanding and flexibility regarding schedules and time off.
cons: It is difficult to find a downside to working at UBC: the only thing I can think of is that the work wasn't always the most stimulating and after a couple of years started to feel repetitive.

job_title: Electrical Engineering Student in Vancouver, BC
pros: Very competitive pay, with excellent resources available for any direction your research may take you. They offer a very wide variety of research areas, and are at (or very near) the top of the field with many cutting edge technologies. The professors who run the labs are extremely competent. They help to give your project direction, as well as allowing you the freedom to take your project in a whole new direction.
cons: Not many. Only thing that comes to mind, is the lack of encouragement while the professors are on sabbatical, but I guess that isn't the Universities fault as much as it is my timing.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: Great professors, interesting classes and engaged students. All of the classes and the work that you do to help the instructor, benefit your career in many ways, like widens your understanding of the film industry, helps you understand the people who will go to work in the field, helps you to learn many different useful skills.
cons: The only downside is the assignment of TA positions - all three years you will get an offer either only before a week when you have to start working or even one day before the actual work. All communication with department seems very slow and it doesn't help to build your schedule properly.

review_title: Good for your pension, bad for your health
job_title: Technician IV/Research Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: The campus is beautiful, if you can away from your desk cave.
cons:
Systemic transphobia, homophobia, and poor management throughout administration. Very little oversight regarding health and safety at the departmental level. HR only serves to back up abusive and authoritarian management style. Departmental administration is often undertrained, and nepotistic. Sexual harassment, classism, racism are not confronted unless the accused is an unknown person. Poor to no onboarding for new staff, high turnover rate due to mental stress. Unions are unable to provide safe and healthy workplace generally. 
Heads of department behave like despots. No opportunity for staff feedback. Hierarchy and increased tuition $$$ is the most important aspect over everything.

review_title: A great time and awesome learning experience
pros: Great people to work with and UBC is situated on a beautiful campus. Amazing opportunities. Awesome benefits package.
cons: Pay wasn't always comparable to private sector. Leadership puts out great ideas but often fails in implementation. Parking pass even for staff is $100/month. Food options are expensive on campus.

job_title: Project Support Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: Good benefits, convenient location - because it's a student environment, there are lots of good places to eat, it's convenient to get whatever you need. Most people are nice and helpful.
cons: Too many students can sometimes bog down the work environment. It is not too convenient to commute to on a daily basis, depending on where you live. Lots of politics in the work place. Too much beaurocracy. Not a good place to work as a fresh grad because of slow pace. Hard to work up the ladder unless you are exceptional and lucky with open positions.

job_title: Desktop Support Technician in Vancouver, BC
pros:
Informal work environment. Lots of autonomy. Nice people, nice bosses. 
Working with professors was great because they are always super friendly and very appreciative of your help. 
Most of the trouble tickets you get require in-person visits instead of solving over the phone.
cons:
They were kind of cheap. Ticket system was homebrewed and not the best. No USB thumbdrives given, so you would have to walk back to the office to borrow the boss's one when needed.
They tried to cheap us out at first by paying less than they initially offered ($3 less per hour). I complained though and they payed us when they initially promised.

pros:
1. You can learn a lot from talented peers. 
2. Supervisors are really helpful when you need them. 
3. The University provide family housing with reasonable price.
cons:
1. There are constructions all over the places, which makes the working environment not enjoyable. 
2. Too much turnover on the top management team. Hopefully, the new president will make it more sustainable. 
3. Compensation/salary is only OK given the living cost in Vancouver.

review_title: Great *IF* you train in the right lab
pros: My boss was/scientific advisor was superlative.  He was a good man that took care of our lab group.  He cared about us as people and as researchers.
cons: The University itself is terrible.  It is a property development company before being an academic institution.  Dozens of high paid administrators are hired to have impressive titles - administrators tend to slow research and innovation more than anti-science types.  The reputation of the school is buoyed by select researchers like my previous boss.  Go else where.

pros:
-City is beautiful
-Lots of facilities to do state of the art research
cons:
-Very little pay, barely able to survive. Probably 1/2 minimum wage after paying tuition and taking account for extra hours.
-Almost non existent extra financial support to students besides major national scholarships which are very very competitive
-Bad benefits
-Vancouver is extremely expensive to live in, 50-75% of your net salary will be used to rent a single bedroom in a shared apartment
-University does not support student's well being at all
-Very minimal extracurricular activity to promote socializing between students
-City does not have many career options after graduation

pros: A learning institution, which means you may be working with or supporting students and researchers eager to advance knowledge. Decent salary but hard to keep up with cost of living. Great benefits including tuition credit. Beautiful location once you deal with the commute.
cons: Poor opportunities for career progression. Lots of "dead wood" employees and faculty who should either be helped to perform better, fired or retired. Hard to find decent rental accommodation close by that doesn't eat up half your salary.

pros:
Some of the people that work there are the some of the best people I have ever met. I never felt like UBC deserved such hard workers with so much heart and integrity. UBC doesn't recognize and reward individuality. UBC rewards people for doing what they expect you to do and furthering their goals. 
Some people think the benefits are great at UBC but they are over-rated. They just make you so comfortable that you never want to leave. Also some benefits seem better than they are- like the free tuition. It is never really free and no one has time or energy to take class or can fit the classes they actually need or want to study into their schedule. Also you have to jump through the same hoops as regular applicants and that is a real deterent. In the end, very few employees take advantage of the free tuition credits.
cons: I had the misfortune of going through a reorganization and was laid off. My department was replaced and expanded and many of my colleagues who had been with the department the longest and were the most knowledgeable were not offered new roles. Instead these roles were handed to the least experienced staff who had been there the least amount of time. This was really hard for me to experience because I value loyalty and hard work together very highly. I also saw how tremendous these overlooked colleagues were in helping students and couldn't fathom why this wasn't more valuable to management. I didn't fit in here because I am someone who is constantly pushing the envelope and thinking creatively which scares institutions like UBC that prefer the status quo and blind acceptance. I was a square peg trying to fit into a round hole. I don't regret working there I just regret staying for so long. I felt creatively empty and demoralized at the end of it. I desperately wanted to make a contribution but was never given the opportunity. If you like predictability and want to rise the top by doing what you are told and stroking egos then this is the place for you.

pros: Good research is done at UBC, but really depends a lot on your research supervisor.
cons: Work is poorly compensated. Management is disjoint and unfocused. Heavy burden is played on individual uncovering the correct bureaucratic. Caustic 'do nothing' culture which endeavors to prevent work from being accomplished.

review_title: Everything depends on a department and for who you work.
pros: Health insurance, maternity leaves are financed by the school, helpful HR, possibility to take teaching workshops.
cons: If you are working under PI supervision, choose the right person. Once you signed a contract nobody cares how much you work. It can be 12 hours 6 days a week and your PI will be unhappy with your work. I saw people who were postdocs for 10 years! They were transferring from one PI to another without any career growth.

pros:
To be a staff of the University of British Columbia is very interesting and very challenging and you
will be pround to tell your friends that you are working in the second largest university of Canada.
cons:
You cannot work overtime without pay because it is under the CUPE 2950 and very strict to impose
and you will be in trouble if you insist to work beyond your time unless if it is overtime with pay.

review_title: A very nice place to work in an expensive city
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Vancouver, BC
pros:
This is a world class university. Here you will have the chance to work with people who are among the biggest names in their field.
Vancouver is a beautiful city to live in.
cons:
Vancouver is a very expensive city and the salary doesn't compensate for that very well.
Also, the finance department seemed to have a lot of difficulty getting salaries correct. I know of several people who had multiple issues with the finance department.

job_title: Work Learn Student in Vancouver, BC
pros: The work learn program is focused on helping students develop their professional skills. They give students opportunities for feedback and are typically flexible with scheduling, such that students are able to balance their work and academic life. Pay is typically a lot better than minimum wage as well!
cons: The work learn program is very competitive, so some students may simply not get any opportunity even if they are good candidates for the job. Furthermore, often offices will be re-hiring the same students, thus, making it even more difficult for new work learn applicants.

review_title: Very difficult working environment unless you have a skillset that can't easily be replaced. Some ethical concerns.
job_title: Advancement Services Employee in Vancouver, BC
pros:
Interesting work.
Some positions are paid well. Can ask for mid-point salary if you are expected to hit the ground running.
Some positions receive a lot of recognition.
Some positions have great work/life balance.
The annual vacation allotment is generous. Can negotiate for more vacation time when hired.
cons:
Low morale.
Very few career opportunities, if any, though they say there are to keep you motivated. 
Every aspect of your performance is analyzed. 
Bi-annual performance reviews.
Passive aggressiveness.
The contents of your email account are not private.

pros:
- Free access to pretty much any and all important research papers
- Teaching assistant hours are very flexible and pay is more than fair
- High flexibility given to pursue your research how you please
cons:
- Tuition is only increasing while the same cannot be said for salaries
- Stressful environment with little mentoring: everything is self-taught. This may be highly dependent on which lab you work for. But I've worked for multiple labs and this is always the case. It's much better to just get a job elsewhere if you're looking for professional development.

pros: Benefits are good, campus is pretty
cons: Salary is low. Supervisor shows up at noon.  Chaotic management style, disorganized, diminishing accomplishments, cornering employees in their office over inconsequential misunderstandings, Honestly, the worst place I have worked in 20 odd years of working. I see people in tears on a weekly basis.  Anxiously seeking another job. HR just gives snotty glances and does nothing, while turnover is clearly high for a reason.

pros:
It is a fairly relaxed place to work; depending on the department, business casual or casual attire is appropriate.
Good benefits, including free classes.
The campus is lovely and is in a beautiful location.
cons:
Lots of red tape -- both management and the unions are very bureaucratic. 
Not much room for promotion if your position is part of the union.
Low pay compared to other places.
Pay differs widely from one department to another.

review_title: Overall a nice place to work.
pros:
Nice working environment,  nice campus, very nice people, good life/work balance.
It is more relaxed then in the private world you are not rushed into jobs , you have time to plan ahead and do proper research.
cons: It is difficult to advance in your carreer, many positions are very static or only people from inside the departments are promoted to available job openings.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: Very good pay. Reasonable hours.
cons: Level of guidance is entirely dependent on professor. Some TAs are teaching classes with almost no support. This can be extremely stressful for anyone that cares about the quality of instruction they are providing for their students.

review_title: A good university for graduate study but pays low
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Kelowna, BC
pros: Small campus. Friendly environment. Good relationship between supervisor and graduate students.
cons: The payments are too low. No increase over the years. It is really difficult for the graduate students to live a decent life with such paychecks. NSERC is also to blame. They should increase research funding for the graduate studies otherwise there will be less and less qualified students coming to Canada. By the way, the work/life balance is also poor.

pros: Beautiful location, work flexibility and the people I work with.  Working with positive and energetic students.  Get instant gratification from the work I do.  Helping make the world a better place to live.
cons: As with any large organization (16,000 employees) there is lots and lots of bureaucracy.  Although there is also lots of innovation, it takes a long time to implement postive change.

pros: Good benefits and friendly environment, supportive colleagues, chances to switch between and try different departments.  Good for those with family, but not so much for someone looking to develop a high-flying career.
cons: Too bureaucratic and too much red tape in some of the processes; does not feel innovative enough for a place which should be more forward thinking.

pros: Beautiful place to work, especially if it's the first experience of working in research environment. I benefited because I worked and gained salary and responsibly each time. Lots of opportunity to move from different dept or units within UBC. Another positive aspect I think is that you don't have the same pressure that you might have in a private company
cons: It's not an ideal place to work if you want to build up your career. Most of the time labs have a limitation amount of money to spend for research

pros:
- It is a very well organised company with very respectful staff and faculty
- There is good direction provided and support
-Benefits are good
- The buildings and office space are comfortable and the campus as a whole is very beautiful
- A wonderful work environment which provides for good work/life balance
cons: - After a few years the work can become mundane and while there is room for growth within the organisation it tends to be at a slow pace. If you are ambitious, this may not be the right environment for you.

review_title: A review from a tiny unit on UBC Vancouver campus
pros:
The job classification system I found transparent and helpful (e.g. the job codes and levels listed on the job description)
(I happen to be in a part of UBC that I love)
cons:
Since UBC is so large, the experience will largely depend on what department/team you are in so it could be a "hit-or-miss"
Since UBC is so large, there will be things that are out of your control

pros: Autonomy. Ideas and suggestions listened to and taken seriously. Hours flexible. Great deal of personal satisfaction with job being done. Helped my prof with literature searches and assisted a PhD student with construction of his project.
cons: Some very long days. Had a problem when we started the project and I was there until midnight. Not unwilling to put in the extra time when needed as some days were lighter.  Only a summer job. Wish it could be full time.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: Great infrastructure and funding available for graduate students.  It has a beautiful campus.  It's a very well known university with some great connections
cons: Not enough supervision.  Research faculty is not very enthusiastic about teaching  which can reduce the lecture quality.  Living on and around the campus is extremely expensive.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: The opportunity to make extra income as a graduate student while on campus is really great. Decent income as well some experience of dealing with mentoring or teaching students.
cons: Hard to get the initial TA position since so many other people also apply for the positions. Once someone is able to secure a TA position, they are typically the ones to TA again the following term/year.

review_title: Really great experience with some great people
pros: Great environment, both for working and academics. I got to be around some great and brilliant people, and learn a lot from them. They had a great balance for work, if you were getting your project done it didn't matter how much time you spent in the lab. The professor I worked under was outstanding, and understanding. I always felt that I wasn't doing enough and she always encouraged me.
cons: Lower pay than industry standard ( I really think it opened more doors though).

pros: The environment and culture at top shelf.  Great salary and benefits, and the bonus of attending free courses for professional development is amazing.  Love working in a community of life long learners
cons: The unions and beuraucracy can make navigating the academic/administrative world difficult.  Sometimes if feels like UBC is two different companies for that reason.  The 99 Bee Line is also a drag... can't wait till they get a fixed LTR link from commercial to campus!

review_title: UBC is great but uncertain times ahead
pros: Reasonably good pay and benefits, beautiful environment and opportunities to try different types of work.
cons: The outlook for professional staff are uncertain with the leadership changing. Some think UBC has hired too many professional staff and cuts could be coming.  Middle managers tend to be hired with little management experience.

review_title: Your small team can make it all worthwhile!
pros: Youthful environment, interesting and meaningful work. Administration places a strong emphasis on safety and wellness.
cons:
Your experience depends largely on local unit leadership. This can change drastically with the appointment of a new Dean/Head.

Work culture is very hierarchical with the clerical staff at the bottom, management staff in the middle, and faculty on a completely different plane.

review_title: Derogatory attitude towards non academoc professionsals - don't even think of working here if you aren't in an academic
pros: Attractive physical environment. Good pension. Nice people.
cons:
Extremely incompetent management, heavily political environment, not listened to (at all) unless you have an academic position. Academics are elistist and have a terribly derogatory attitude towards non academic professional staff.

Lots of backstabbing.

pros:
Great Benefits - health & education funds
Generous holiday allowance - starting at 3 weeks off 
Good contribution to RRSP account
cons:
It really depends what department you are in, as the people make or break the experience
Working with academics can be very challenging
Can be bureaucratic and slow moving for certain things

job_title: Work Learn Communications & Grants Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: Can consistently count on 10 hours of work a week. The wage is good, almost 20$ an hour. The work environment at Xwi7xwa Library is great, and my co workers are very nice. I am treated very professionally.
cons: I'm not 100% sure what my role is. My supervisors are pleased with the work I do. Yet, the administrative lag of the whole library system is very confusing, and makes it difficult to know the status of the projects we're working on (re funding etc)

review_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant - Job is interesting though not well paid.
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: Great to make contacts and learn more regarding specific research topics. It was well worth the time to investigate the effects of different additives on ceramic structures.
cons: It was boring at times and repetitive. Sometimes, the management didn't really seem to care too much and didn't supervise very well.

review_title: Lots of ammenities and perks for staff, CUPE positions are not well compensated.
pros:
- great facilities (food options, rec facilities, discounts on campus)
- ability to take courses for free!
- great benefits
cons:
- CUPE positions are not well paid
- location is very far away from the rest of the city - I had a one hour commute from East Vancouver
- there is no standardization of salaries, position titles among Faculties

review_title: Disappointing work environment - a handful of employees manage to ruin it for all the rest.
pros: Lots of great interaction with students while teaching, ample opportunity to discuss ideas and new solutions to problem that pop up while teaching.
cons: Lab managers do not empower teaching assistants; too much emphasis put on experience instead of competency, which leads to a needlessly political work environment.

pros: As a research assistant, you have extremely flexible work schedules as they will schedule around your preferences. Most of the time, the job is relatively simple and you can multitask during the process.
cons: UBC is relatively located in a remote place and it may be inconvenient for those that do not have class/do not live on campus to commute all the way for a few hours of work. Work also comes irregularly and is dependent on how many people they require

pros: Great intelligent people to work with, great compensation and there is definitely room for growth. As well as the beautiful location and easy access via public transportation, good benefits.
cons: Busy transportation lines because of students, constant construction that you will need to navigate around, some public matters or negative media that some alumni or affiliates of the university will be upset over.

review_title: Working in a great university as researcher
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: The best part of my experience as a full-time TA and RA at the Department of Statistics, the University of British Columbia is having lots of supportive faculties and TAs as well as friendly administrators. The working experience is really cool for me.
cons: Well, they term the positions for the graduate student is "full-time" TA/RA. But, it is very tough for an international student to live in costly Vancouver with this salary.

pros: My supervisor and teammates are actually very helpful during meetings to establish a good connection with everyone else on the team. It makes for good days at work and little stress.
cons: The work experience seems to not translate in the best manner from inside a school to outside of a school. It's less "impressive" to have worked at a school, I guess.

job_title: Writing Centre Tutor in Vancouver, BC
pros: Great way to earn an extra income as a student, with rock solid pay for a part-time job. Easy access to reference letters, and a good way to network as a bonus. I'd venture to say that this is the best work-study position available at UBC.
cons: No cons really; my own writing improved as a consequence of working here and getting trained by the centre. Yeah, I really can't think of a single con.

review_title: Great students job with good pay.
pros: Great pay for a student job and there are a lot of great people to work with as well. There is also the chance to get promoted to a team leader which has more responsibility, more hours, and more skills to obtain.
cons: Not much of a con for a student job since it fits well for our schedule. However, there are times when the schedule could be hectic especially when there are multiple home games occurring in the week.

pros: Excellent University that has plenty of resources for students, staff, and visitors. The infrastructure is the best and the staff are very helpful and well prepared. The campus and Vancouver are very beautiful.
cons: Housing is very expensive on-campus and off-campus. Vancouver is very expensive compared to other cities in North America. So, don't expect to have too many savings after you finished grad school unless you have another job on the side

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: I worked with a professor through the Work-Learn program, which enables graduate and undergraduate students to gain work-related experience through opportunities at the university.  Good program, and decent pay for a research assistant.
cons: Sometimes my work was more of an assistant role then a research assistant.  Also, the program maxes out at 10 hours a week, but does not guarantee the hours, so the hours can really depend on the professor's schedule which can make it difficult to plan for.

pros: A bunch of different opportunities for expanding your skill set, great location, employer is fair, good community and workplace environment. A lot of effort is made to build employee community.
cons: Comes with all of the politicking associated with large universities. Organizational structure is pretty typical, but new management is changing things slowly in some departments. Some of the work can get pretty static and tedious unless you make a concerted effort to ask for and lead your own projects.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Vancouver, BC
pros: It was excellent to work with top-notch scientists under well-funded environment.  I worked there also in 2002-2004 and the facility has upgraded significantly since then, and the access to facility has improved a lot.
cons: Not any cons that I can think of at the moment.

pros: The university is in Vancouver. It has one of the prettiest campus in the world and Vancouver is a very nice city to live. People there are nice.
cons: Depends on whom you work for, some may be quite pushy. Some tasks maybe a bit tedious and may not be very helpful to gain research skills.

pros: Generous Benefits, Generous Time Off, Beautiful Campus, Generous Retirement Plan, some nice people, significant training opportunities.
cons: Conservative management, disorganized administration, not innovative or open to change, bureaucratic, few resources, homogenous staff (i.e. not very diverse, typically older, typically female), credential inflation (i.e. would hire people who are overqualified and therefore displeased, bored, or not challenged by jobs).

review_title: Generally a great place to work
pros:
- positive atmosphere
- great team
- interesting topics to work with
- constantly changing workplace
- as a staff member working with faculty, I am constantly learning
cons:
- attitudes of some senior staff
- ancient computers/technology
- status quo is accepted
- guidelines for workplace behaviour are not accessible nor followed

review_title: Graduate student research and teaching assistant
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: I am getting a lot of experience from the work and networking opportunities. It is also a good environment of young people
cons: High tuition fees, even only when I am writing my thesis. The hourly pay is less than what I would get at McDonalds

review_title: Working for UBC is a fantastic during graduate studies
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: Payment was prompt and regular. Resources were laid out as needed for information and help. It is well posted that TA's have union help and how to receive that help.
cons: Taxation rates were not correct. Parking for employees is no different than the public, which is very expensive and can accumulate over time, especially when work periods are not standardized in daily time and frequency.

review_title: Pretty well depends almost entirely on your supervisor
pros: Lots of different research options, beautiful campus, great facilities for the most part, awesome to live in Vancouver while doing research
cons: Same problems that plague academia elsewhere: you are sometimes dependent on the character of your supervisor. If you have a good supervisor, great, if not, it can sink you

pros: Good flexibility in hours.  Good experience to work in confidential environments with students. Friendly co-workers. No late night work or Sunday work.
cons: Management is disorganized. They do not respect their commitments to their employees. They will ask you to work hours after you are scheduled to end.  Little or no summer work. Poor planning.

pros: Working as a TA is fun if you enjoy teaching. Collaborating with other TAs was also a good experience. The experience improves not only your teaching abilities, but also your abilities as a public speaker, as multiple tutorials (lectures) are given to undergraduate students weekly.
cons: Some professors need greater involvement with the TAs to provide a better learning experience for undergraduates. Greater salary to adjust for high Vancouver living expenses.

pros: Nice environment to do academic research with people who have cutting-edge professional knowledge. People are nice, the campus is nicer. Definitely worths going for graduate studies.
cons: Transportation is not as good as it could be. Being at the corner of Vancouver, you would have to commute by buses every day if you don't live nearby.

pros: Continuous learning opportunities - formal and informal such as instructional skills, management development and structured networking opportunities with professional staff. Very flexible, family-friendly approach and policies
cons: As a publicly funded university, the salaries are not the best, particularly for non-academic or beginning academic staff.

pros: A very diverse atmosphere at a top notch educational institution, in a beautiful city with room for growth in many directions. Excellent benefits and pension.
cons: Since my employment at UBC, there has been multiple political instances from both the Management, Directors and university President with all 3 of which have left and been replaced (or not replaced yet).

review_title: Good pay, Close to city, good networking potential.
pros: Get to see the pilot plant facility and use different lab equipment. Also work with a research engineer and project manager. Great location to work in beautiful UBC.
cons: The work is repetitive and not very interesting. Sometimes you get bad smells from the old pulp but that is fine.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: Good company at the lab.  Great academic environment.  Many opportunities to go to international conferences and present your research project. Offers masters degree in biology i.e. doctors degree not only option.
cons: Supervisor could have been more supportive. Limited course selection. Would have wanted more opportunities to  develop different laborotory skills - was limited to current research.

pros: Great school academically, they really push their students to their full potential. The campus is absolutely beautiful.
cons: Rains too often, profs don't take into consideration that you are in other classes too! Such a heavy workload!

pros: TAship to lots of students. I think they wanna have TAs as many as possible. I got the admission with funding package. so TA is part of my job
cons: Not too bad. And it's likely to have a better opportunity to earn additional money, as long as you are willing to help other exams.

review_title: Great place to work in higher ed, but highly political environment at times
pros: Transparent and generous compensation package compared to other institutions in BC, starting salaries and salary progression, opportunities for advancement, good leaders (varies by department), forward thinking institution, great work-life balance, beautiful campus.
cons: I've heard that compensation for standard business functions are typically below market, but for student/learning related roles it's above market. Highly political environment that take times to learn to navigate and it still feels uncomfortable.

pros: People were really nice, my work was interesting, I had great benefits.
cons: Your everyday work environment really depends on your lab and supervisor. In my experience, the cons are that I had to work overtime but was not paid for it, the work environment and the division of tasks was disorganized at times, and I encountered some unsafe work situations. Thankfully UBC has started to make more of an effort to identify and deal with unsafe work situations.

review_title: I built my logic based on this position
pros: There is a hood employee vacation rate. The job is stable and the pay is fairly high. The work place enviroment is stress free
cons: It's is far away from my home. The jobs are not permanent unless you hold a high academic degree. And overall not a good location.

pros: Nice buildings and environment.  Can be improved with relationships among people by skills training, minds with others in mind, and equity review.
cons: Rarely would people care for one, especially management, and treated like short of dirt or a bridge, or like fresh out from high school or alien.  Salary was like treatment, particularly for a group.

pros: nice campus, nice scenery, lots of different things to do day to day.  always gauranteed work even in the slower months which is good
cons: lack of opportunity , no real job advancment, wages havent matched the other sectors as inflation has gone up quite a lot in recent years

pros: Great benefits, opportunities for education, very flexible working schedule, multiple work sites, lots of support from employment group, very dynamic research can be possible
cons: Salary could be better (compared to private sector), the experience depends on the group that you are working with - so there's no real across-the-board standards for workplace experience

review_title: Lots of interesting opportunities, highly competitive
pros: Being a part of a very big research university that has a medical school and receives lots of government funding. And the campus is beautiful!
cons: Depending on where you work, the culture can be a bit toxic (non-supportive, negatively competitive where team members are pitted against one another, a lot of schmoozing rather than doing good work to keep your job safe.)

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: Amazing environment to work at. Great research opportunities and good job and internship opportunities. Strong alumni network that come and talk to you about new opportunities in the industry.
cons: Vancouver is an expensive place to live. Incoming students need to consider living cost and tuition. There are a lot of technical startups but not too many big company headquarters. So graduating from an American university would give you more number of opportunities.

pros: Good pay, the people are pretty nice. The campus is also pretty nice, which is a bonus, espsecially in the summer months.
cons: Work is horrendously boring, things get done ridiculously slowly due to all the bureaucracy and hoops required to get projects through. Not recommended for entry-mid-level students.

pros:
- Good benefits
- Flexible work environment (depends entirely on the department/group you work with)
- Interesting research and teaching happening all around
- Very structured salary and benefits
cons:
- Difficult working with faculty (highly knowledgeable in narrow fields, barely any common sense)
- Very structured salary and benefits

review_title: Highly gratifying; got to work with very smart people.
pros:
- Being at the leading edge of research
- Great potential for interdisciplinary collaborations
- Opportunity to make good connections in academia and industry
cons:
- No benefits of any kind
- Low salary / high expectations
- Have to live in Vancouver west-side (more expensive), or elsewhere but with a bad commute

pros: Good Pension and benefits, Lots of Vacation Time, Good Work/ Life Balance, Beautiful Campus & location within Vancouver. Great public transit access.
cons: "Old School" Management style, Not progressive, Bureaucratic with little productivity. My department had a very unethical leadership team and did not seem to align with the vision/ mission of the university.

review_title: Overall enjoyable work environment...if you work in the right department.
pros: There are educational tuition benefits. Friendly co-workers. Natural settings.
cons: Salaries much lower than private sector, except for senior management. Probably biggest con. Salaries may not increase year-to-year as much as private industry. Layoffs in last few years seem like a cost-cutting measure to replace long-term employees with lower-paid employees.

review_title: Worked as a teaching assistant, not adequate compensation for the work, time and effort that is put in while trying to s
pros: I appreciated the opportunity to do it, it was great working with students and helping them grow and be challenged by the course matter
cons: Alot of time for marking required, large amounts of work in a short period of time, can be stressful deadlines, not alot of direction with course material.

pros: Wonderful benefits, great work-life balance. Commitment to competitive compensation (at the 50th percentile) makes UBC a good choice, particularly if you're risk-averse and want perks like great leave options, a pension, etc.
cons: Some departments are slow-moving or overly bureaucratic. Academics in leadership doesn't guarantee good business knowledge or strategic thinking, departments are too autonomous in some ways, but centralization leads to ridiculous bureaucracy. The wrong people get fired and button-pushers stay.

job_title: Front Desk Clerk in Kelowna, BC
pros: The people in the office are very friendly and it is a very positive atmosphere. They are very encouraging and supportive to help you learn.
cons: In the summer, the guests may have unrealistic expectations which places you in very difficult positions where you have to balance being flexible with the guest as well as be firm and uphold the policies of the department.

review_title: UBC - pretty good for a University
pros: Had a great manager who was very helpful when I needed it, but very happy to let me work on my own as well. Considering it was an internship the pay was quite good.
cons: part time, no contract, no benefits.  at the same time, they don't expect as much.  parking is terrible.  better to take the bus

pros: The university is still growing and has great potential. I enjoyed the international flair.
cons: Sometimes seemed like a high school and less than a "mature" university (compared to European Universities). The work speed often seemed slow and senior employes had long lunch breaks and spend hours decorating the office for christmas.

pros: The health and parental benefits are very strong.  Eye-glasses and paramedical are generously compensated.
cons: The culture rewards mediocrity.  The university exists to hire overpaid, out-of-touch administrators.  The infrastructure is garbage:  I work in a plant department without a greenhouse.  Sure I can walk 10 minutes to a greenhouse elsewhere on campus but that is not acceptable.

pros:
- Good benefits, tuition waivers, pension plan, vacation days
- Many excellent co-workers who are knowledgeable and very helpful
- Good work-life balance
- Professional and respectful work environment across the campus
cons:
- Low employee morale
- No work satisfaction
- Employees are not valued
- No interesting projects anymore
- No investment in modern technologies anymore
- High staff turn over in the past year (20% turn over), driving the best employees to other companies
- Used to be an excellent place to work where everyone worked well together but has turned for the worse in the past 2 years
- Communication is one-way, from top management downwards, command and control
- Bad upper management who believes in vendors' PR and overhyped silver bullet solutions rather than own employees
- Everyone is told what and how to do their job which can be seen by the purchase of an old low-tech third-party system and development environment with a very limited feature set
- Custom development is frowned upon and is seen as ineffective, inefficient and unmaintainable
- People are treated as replaceable parts
- UBC IT makes town hall promises with out-dated third-party technologies without accuracy or validation from technical staff
- Very political environment
- Lack of transparency from management
- Does not value employee personal and professional growth anymore
- Dysfunctional organization
- UBC IT is a dinosaur and is not an innovative IT department who value their human infrastructure

review_title: Top of the pyramid is white
pros: Met great student leaders who have positive visions for the school
cons: Having to report to higher-ups who are majority white straight male/females who don't look anything like me or know how to behave towards people of color

pros: The department size is perfect and the department manager while I was there is extremely good at her job. She ensures that staff morale is up and productive.
cons: Not a lot of growth opportunities internally given that it is a small department. Some tasks may appear mundane at times and repetitive.

job_title: Research Engineer, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering in Vancouver, BC
pros:
- Opportunity to work alongside graduate students, postdocs and professors on interesting projects
- Flexible work schedule
- Good extended health and perks
- Excellent networking opportunities through industry events and academic talks
cons:
- As expected in academia, salaries are typically below industry average and funding and resources may be limited for equipment
- The level of workplace safety as well as workplace tidiness can vary between different labs and supervisors (some labs are really disorganized)

review_title: Just avoid this hell-hole like a plague!!
pros: None! It has no redeeming qualities! Nada! Zilch!!
cons: Lots! Starving wages. Slave-like labour. Lots of teaching duties. Outrageously expensive city: with the starving wages they pay you, you'll be dreaming about having two meals a day. The administrative staff are condesending and unfriendly. The profs could not care less for your well-being. And on top of it all, the weather is positively miserable, which is probably why everyone is so difficult to deal with as well. Just go to Toronto or Montreal or even Waterloo would be better.

review_title: Outstanding work environment and atmosphere - By far the best place I have worked for
pros: An amazingly great workplace environment and I consider myself very fortunate to be part of it. Great relationships and inclusion. I'm enormously proud to work with the greatest group of people in a harmonious atmosphere.
cons: Commute time but that is really minor compared to the Pros.

pros: They were always very understanding of personal events occurring and helped work around my schedule as a student. The pay was also pretty high for a student working part time.
cons: I didnt have any issues with my workplace or the people working there. Everything went very smoothly

review_title: Working as a PhD research and teaching assistant at UBC
pros:
A lots of opportunities for personal and professional growth
Wonderful place to build a network
Varieties of options to learn new professional skills
A good start point for career in teaching and research
cons:
Low paid jobs.
Being over-qualified for most of available jobs in BC.
Hard to create boundary between research work and life.
Challenge of defining the tasks

job_title: Academic Program Coordinator in Vancouver, BC
pros:
- flexible working times
- extra flexibility for employee's academic schedule
- as an employee you feel that you are being valued
- your growth is important and you are able to choose the areas you want to work on for your growth
cons:
- feedback is not always very clear
- your manager may not always be available most of the time and that can affect your performance, getting feedback etc

pros: Fast paced.  A lot of room for advancement, until you reach the higher levels of management.  Excellent learning opportunities, wonderful place to network and make friends.
cons: As with many large corporations, information is not always consistent and can lead to problems,  Too many chefs in the kitchen.  The climate has changed into a corporate one where money seems to be most important.

pros: Professional development activities for employees, room to move around other jobs at ubc, depends on your employment group - can be part of a union, coworkers great, depends which manager you get, can be good or bad
cons: Depends which manager you get, not much room to explore duties outside of your current position, salary fixed

review_title: Typical experience being a graduate student
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant/Instructor in Vancouver, BC
pros: UBC allows their graduate students to be full instructors for first year math classes which allows them to build up their CV.
cons: There is a lot of bureaucracy at this university and there is a lot of extra paperwork involved in the process. Organizational skills are lacking when it comes to assigning teaching and TAship duties. Often the number of hours are unfairly distributed.

review_title: Faculty of Arts Peer Advising Office
pros: Good place to work. Great close knit community at the Faculty of Arts Advising Office.
cons: Office felt understaffed at times, given the number of students that needed to be serviced and the available advisors on call.

pros: A great place to learn and do research. Highly experienced researchers and Professors. Interesting topics
cons: The salary is very low. You need to work extra hours to get graduated and you need to always pay attention to your account balance.

pros: Stipend is enough to live, don't expect to have savings if you pay rent. UBC has a lot of resources and equipment to conduct your research, should be valuable experience to your next employer.
cons: Funding extensions can be tough depending on your supervisor. I worked without a stipend for the last 8 months of my PhD program. Try to finish on time or early if you can.

review_title: Good place to work, not easy to get by on offered money
pros:
- great university, very strong in research
- beautiful location within very livable city
- very good support for teaching development (TAG institute)
cons: - low salaries make it difficult for teaching assistants to get by in Vancouver, which is an expensive city to live in

review_title: Casual interviews for graduate studies or undergradaute research assistant
pros: Working in an academic field where the setting is a lot more casual than in the industry. Research positions offer a lot of freedom and supports from different mentors other than your direct supervisor.
cons: Research funding cut from the government affected the salary for graduate students and research assistants. Lack of funding made scholarship very competitive.

review_title: Great Place but not for me
pros: You can take free courses in anything you want.
cons: There is no flexibility because it is a union run environment. If you don't have a Master's degree your opinion doesn't count. In my area the environment is very hostile and negative. Staff are always complaining about their bosses or their work environment but keep working there just because of the pension plan.

review_title: Study and work at the same time!
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros:
My office is in the same building where I take most of my classes.
Get to use the facilities of faculty members.
Great for students who want to get some research experience, learn and make some money at the same time.
cons:
Few opportunities for undergraduates.
If you want one you have to try hard and contact a lot of professors willing to work with you!

pros: I enjoyed the flexible hours, excellent medical / dental disability.  Free tuition was an added bonus.  Could work at  different work sites
cons: hard to move up; sometimes I would be bored.  I had to use my own car and fuel to work at the different sites

review_title: Great place to start your career
job_title: Human Resources Administrative Clerk in Vancouver, BC
pros:
Great benefits including pension matching and education credits. 
Supportive in your future moves. 
Good training opportunities. 
Good internal job postings so there is an opportunity to move laterally within the university
cons:
The union limits any pay raises so there aren't a lot of opportunities for quick pay raises. 
Low salaries
Slow to get to if you don't live close by

review_title: Fabulous place to work, too bad wage is lower than others
pros: Amazing supportive staff, other instructors are very helpful and kind. Great campus and field trip options. Lots of choice and autonomy in how you teach and different program options.
cons: Big university = a lot of top down decisions, very political. Feel very small on campus in the big picture. Salary is not great in comparison to other colleges.
