review_title: Good place to start your career
job_title: Teaching Lab Tech in Kelowna, BC
pros: Because it is working in a university, people are very friendly, and always glad to help -- you learn a lot like a student. The benefits are great too.
cons: the salary is not very high (just average). but thinking about you won't be laid off in a normal case. your job is very secured, with plenty of holidays, plenty of free times.

review_title: UBC can be good start point
pros:
Great benefits 
Lots of perks around campus
Nice location 
Easy commute 
Generous vacation time
cons:
Budget slashes limit what can do 
Many positions limited/cut to 60% FT 
Pay rate lower than should be for positions 
Too many managerial levels of fluff 
Limited advancement - lots of middle age 
High turnover in entry level

review_title: Jobs that pay well for what actually gets done
pros: Safe work environment, great benefits
cons: Competitive upward mobility, but the unproductive union environment makes you realize why very little gets done efficiently

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Vancouver, BC
pros:
working in a university provides access to a continuous learning experience and cutting edge technologies. 
Access to student mentorship and assisstance
cons: There is a limited number of positions in academia, which makes difficult long term planning.

pros: Great hours and benefits. Friendly and down-to-earth people. Great work-life balance especially if you have kids. Good job security.
cons: Too much bureaucracy.  Very slow moving projects. Would benefit by picking up the pace a bit.

review_title: Great place to work with talented professionals
pros: Nice Leadership people who always be supportive for personal career goals and balance work and life. (at least my department, so lucky I am)
cons: Commuting to Point gray campus is a little pain either driving or busing. Good news is Skytrain expansion from Commercial station to Point gray campus. Bad news is it would take in 10 ys.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Vancouver, BC
pros: Good labs, good research, great location.
cons:
Frustrating changes in administration policy. I was originally recruited as a grad student on the promise that my tuition would be waived once I did my comprehensive exams. Policy was changed without notice before that happened.

Biotech and Pharma are dead here compared to just about any other large west coast city. Few opportunities locally in my field.

review_title: Great university with beautiful campus and comfortable working environment
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: office culture is good, time is flexible
cons: Construction is always on site, need proper planning so that it won't affect the students' experience. Also, guest parking plots are limited, cannot find a place even with visitor parking slips.

review_title: part time work for graduate students at ubc
pros: there are various opportunities available...invigilating exams is one of the best gigs available for graduate students to supplement their fellowship stipend. check out the careers website of ubc frequently for opportunities
cons: the pay is ok, not great..part time jobs do not really add to relevant job experience unless you chose carefully

job_title: Teaching Assistant, Computer Science in Vancouver, BC
pros:
-Got to work closely with good professors in delivering good teaching material
-weekly roundtable meetings added a very open and constructive mindset to the job
-good opportunity to get to know other top-tier peers
cons:
-No very much training is provided, kind of have to just go with what you know from being a student, 
-Some TA's given more responsibilities than others

pros: Academic and intellectual freedom, relaxed working hours, generous vacation policy, good benefits, great location, the chance to work with some very smart people
cons: Extremely crowded transit, often working solo with little guidance or mentoring, must be highly self-motivated, staff are under-appreciated (even management & professional) and sometimes viewed as lesser employees by faculty members, poorly-defined career path for non-faculty

pros: Good benefits, environment and people. Ability to take some continuing studies or credit courses for free.
cons: Faculties, departments and even units sometimes work against each. Often difficult to help students  because there is so much bureaucracy.

pros: Reasonable pay and benefits. I enjoyed many aspects of working at vgh as a ubc employee. One perk is access to the shuttles between vgh, ubc, St. Paul’s, and elsewhere.
cons: Not too many. I think ubc campus itself is a bit hard to get to for most people in the city. Vgh and St. Paul’s are central though.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: Great natural environment. University provides students with housing options that are below the market value. There are many resources to improve yourself.
cons: Very expensive city. There are many job opportunities for engineers and engineering salary cannot to afford to buy houses in Vancouver. If one's supervisor is very pushy, life can be miserable.

review_title: Worklearn Student at the Equity & Inclusion Office
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: There's a wonderful and supportive office culture at the EIO that makes me feel valued as an employee. Decent pay and benefits and numerous opportunities to expand your knowledge base.
cons: Few opportunities for promotion, especially without a Masters/PhD at this particular office. Office culture is not consistent throughout the entire campus.

review_title: A University you can be proud to work for, wonderful students and great benefits.
pros: Great benefits, job security, opportunity to move around within the University. A company you can be proud to work for. Fully supported by management to further training and education.
cons: Difficult to navigate politics and red tape associated with working for a University. Many long-time employees limit forward momentum.

review_title: Good place to work, good people to work with
pros: The benefits are fantastic, great pension, extended health and dental, and flexible working hours. Working a 9 day fort night is still an option at this company in this position!
cons: the pay is disappointing, but they attempt to make up for it with their benefits. Still, it is hard to live on their salary.

pros: Great benefits, lots of vacation, generous sick leave, manageable length of work day, flex days.
cons: Lower than average salary, unjustifiable need to be present in office when work can be done from home.

review_title: Grad student experience in a basic science lab
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: World renowned university, quality of research is high. Its a great place to be a student, i've learned a lot working there
cons: Competitive research environment, can be negative in some labs. Some profs are not supportive of their students (sometimes due to low funding and stress)

pros: good facilities such as offices, modern labs, socializing areas, and outdoor area. Motivating and inspiring workplace, with excellent research team working on relevant projects
cons: very costly to live on campus near the workplace. Very limited time for vacation due to extremely heavy loads of demanded work both experimental and theoretical. Low salary for the duties attributed to the position

review_title: Great to place to work if you can survive a $2 billion organization run by academics with limited management experience
pros: Stimulating environment, helping some of Canada's brightest minds succeed. Support from peers.
cons: Upper management is slow to respond to change. Staff are under-supported and the least respected stakeholder group.

review_title: Advisory, Clerical, Admin, Variety of Roles
pros: Great benefits, room for personal and professional growth, diversity
cons: Difficult to gain employment here as an external employee, hierarchal nature of unions and associations meant that the particular offices I was working in had a disparate proportion of employee motivation and work ethic, which made it pretty disheartening to work there after a while.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in North Vancouver, BC
